text: So important is salt to the Halflings they categorize it by quality, with the finest salts used for fine cooking.
Demand is high for all salts and the Halflings are willing to lose life and limb in its pursuit.
They lick their lips at the huge mounds of salt produced and some Halflings have even been caught in the midst of unsavoury actions.
A small shed were all the farming tools are stored.
The toolmakers produce all the scythes, cleavers and other tools needed by the Halflings.

Halflings scoff at the old slingshots they called catapults, now they are replaced by the real thing.
A workshop to tinker with their prized possession and maybe fashion a few catapults.

Soup, soup, a tasty soup, soup, a spicy carrot and coriander (Chilli chowder). Crouton, crouton, crunchy friends in a liquid broth, I am gazpacho, Oh, I am a summer soup – Traditional Halfling Folk Song
While soup is arguably the most popular Halfling dish, pies baked in a buttery crispy crust... buttery flavoured crust, flaky I mean flaky crust is a very close second.
A place of food galore and pints of beer, that's right, it comes in pints.
Small tobacco plots dot the land, their owners keep most of the crop while selling any excess at the local markets.
Larger in production, tobacco farms are able to cater to the townsfolk who live in the towns across the Moot including its capital Eicheschatten.

Large scale tobacco cultivation uses large swathes of land damaging local countryside. Through economy of scales they are able to service all of the Empire and beyond, making tobacco a lucrative cash crop.
The Halflings have always been attuned with nature but to shy away from industry and embrace the land is truly a wonderful sight.
Halflings have long cultivated tobacco, producing the finest tobaccy throughout the Old World. Gipfel is very much at the heart of this burgeoning industry.
Pigs under halfling care grow so fat and hearty that in dire times they can be ridden into battle. Some muse the pigs fight with such unexpected fury as only to avoid the plate.
Warhorses are far too unwieldy to a halfling and ponies too gentle. As such specially trained cockerels are reared for the halflings to charge into war on.

Tricksy little halflings snatch the eggs and are long gone before the mother even realises. As they tumble down the mountains with their prize, her shrieks and wails can be heard across the mountain tops. This trade has it detractors who see it as a cruel practice.
The Old World has many mouths to feed; grain provides the grist for mills and the base ingredient for spirits.
Farms large and small cross the Old World – growing crops, especially grains, for the crowded towns and cities.
Wherever the forest breaks, large swathes of land are given over to agriculture, most of which is owned by nobles.
Often attached to the walls they protect, the guard house offers shelter and perhaps a hot drink for those on patrol.
The Watch is an organised constabulary; not always honest, but still a capable defensive force should the need arise!
Sigmarite Shrines vary from roadside memorials to more substantial chapels that hold a small congregation.
The Halflings’ diminutive stature masks a ravenous appetite, and as you might expect, highly-developed culinary skills; as such, their cauldrons bubble day and night!
